conclusion: Magnetic flux Φ through a surface is calculated using Φ = B A cos θ.
Given B = 0.1 T (uniform, along +x), A = 0.40 m² (area of the coil), θ = angle between the field direction (+x) and the coil’s outward normal.
Initial position: The coil lies in the horizontal (x-y) plane with outward normal = ± z.
Initial angle θ₁ = 90° (normal is perpendicular to +x), thus Φ₁ = B A cos 90° = 0.
After rotation: The coil is rotated 60° downward about the z-axis.
Rotating about the z-axis does not change the z-component of the normal, but moves the x-y components.
The initial normal (+z) is rotated toward +x by 60°, so the new normal makes an angle θ₂ = 90° − 60° = 30° with +x.
Calculate Φ₂ = B A cos θ₂ = (0.1 T)(0.40 m²) cos 30° = 0.040 Wb × 0.866 = 0.0346 Wb.
Change in flux magnitude: ΔΦ = |Φ₂ − Φ₁| = 0.0346 Wb.
Final answer: The magnetic flux through the coil changes by 3.5 × 10⁻² Wb (approximately 0.035 Wb).
